Galcon is an EXTREMELY fast-paced RTS game. In fact, most Galcon matches take less than a minute to be decided. However, due to its learning curve(plus game-specific quirks), new players will lose matches very quickly, very often.  The game supports microtransactions, but they only include cosmetic items(and it's possible to earn premium currency by winning tournaments, bets or by being given them by other players as a 'good game' reward). However, time played still plays a massive role in how likely a player is to win matches, partly because of skill differences, partly because of an upgrade system based on gameplay frequency allowing players to receive more units at a match's start or produce/move them faster. New players get the advantage of being able to see how many forces opponents have, but this isn't very useful as more skilled players tend to not send all of their ships at once to an enemy planet, can produce enough ships to stop the attack, or send in reinforcements to that planet before your ships arrive to attack it.  The upgrade system uses diminishing returns for match rewards as an anti-poopsocking mechanic similar to CSGO's weekly XP boost/reduction, but with a continuous reset. A player playing for 15 minutes 2~3 times a day is going to get as many points as someone playing continuously, disincentivizing grinding. As such, it's possible to get a sufficiently competitive upgrade level by playing the game casually for 1~2 weeks.

PROS: This game has the best story I have ever seen in any game, I was on the edge of my seat the whole time, and even fell a few times.  The motion capture graphics are the first thing that struck me when playing this game, absolutely stunning, it is optimized so well almost any computer could easily run it at max settings and maintain 60 fps, it even made me cry a little bit. The spaceships in “Galcon 2” are the most realistic physical depictions of spaceships in a video game to date. The amount of technology available overwhelms the player.  FREE GAME! Honestly, this should be priced at $60, maybe even more.  The combat: It is amazing, you have high-detail next gen spaceships at your disposal, ready to attack enemy planets. There are so many different colors you can be, every time I am a new color, I feel like I am being born again, there is so much variety in the colors and the way they attack.  Multiplayer: With internet getting about 4kb/s, I feared I wouldn't be able to play online, boy was I wrong. For the first time, I was able to play an online game without lag. I played with my friends and we worked together to conquer the planets. There are so many different gamemodes to pick from, I felt overwhelmed.   Soundtrack: The music in this makes me want to get up and dance in the middle of my game. The song is constantly stuck in my head all day, but I actually like having this song in my head.  Extras:  +While playing the game there are neutral planets, all of these have clever, realistic names to them, adding more atmosphere to the game.   +I just can't stop talking about the graphics, I literally fell backwards when I first opened the game, I felt as if I was actually in space.   +Online, with eight people playing simultaneously, it's hard to even put into words. There's just so much happening at once, so fast, without any lag too.  Galcon 2 might be the craziest, most intense video game experience I've had in years, but it's also amazing. With stunning graphics, beautiful music, intense, fast paced battles, and so much variety, I couldn't think of one way to improve this game.  Final Score: 11/10 - Best game I have ever played in my life. Game of the century. I would be shocked if I managed to find a game better than this.

Galcon is a simple easy to learn hard to master fps game.Its Graphics are both realistic and simplistic and are not too demanding.The gameplay consists of moving ships to planets to reduce its value until it becomes yours.The goal is to eliminate all enemies.Galcon has many modes to play, the most common is free for all, in which players spawn on random points with a planet and try to conquer everybody else.Its pretty fast paced and until the very end you dont know who will win(unless im playing, heh).The next mode is team mode, the next common and involves two teams fighintg each other, teamwork is very impoortant in this one.The other ones are frenzy, which is free for all but all planets are occupied at the start, and co-op where many people fight a clever(or not so clever)bot. There is no pay to win and all artificial currency is used for cosmetics and running a coustom server, another plus if your willing to spend money.  Galcon is a simple easy to lean game, and is a quick download so check it out!

What a fun game. In Galcon 2, players try to conquer all planets on a map by colonizing planets. Planets under your control will produce ships, which can then be sent to nearby planets to spread your territory. Planets of different sizes will produce ships at different rates, but may cost more or less depending on their production times. So larger planets will produce ships faster, but will be harder to reach and harder to acquire. Smaller planets will be more accessible, but will produce ships slower. The goal of Galcon 2 is to find the right balance and utilize strategy to conquer as many planets as possible.  What I enjoy about Galcon 2 is how simple it is to play. There are no complicated colonization protocols. Any planet may be colonized so long as it contains fewer ships in storage than the amount of ships attacking it. That's it.  However, there is an interesting level of strategy to Galcon 2. First, only gray neutral planets will display colonization cost, ie. a neutral planet might cost 25 ships, making your decision easy in whether to attack it. However, planets colonized by other players will *not* show colonization costs, so pay close attention to ship traffic locations from enemy player activity to guess where their weak spots are.  Second, diplomacy often comes into play in large multiplayer matches. Games will begin as mad rushes to colonize planets and begin producing ships. Then, as the number of neutral planets dwindles, conflicts begin to arise. Players must juggle whether or not they can take over their neighbor's territory, and if doing so will make them appear vulnerable to other players. There is a certain strategy in trying to incite conflicts while biding time to make a proper attack.  Third, though Galcon 2 is typically a free-for-all game (designated team matches exist, but are not as common), teamwork finds itself arriving in the most incredible of situations. In a three-player skirmish, when one player assumes large control of the map, the two other weaker players may realize silently they must work together temporarily to stop the growing threat. Galcon 2 is full of spontaneous blasts of teamwork, but also backstabbing and surprise attacks.  Galcon 2 is one of the most accessible and friendly real-time strategy games on the market today. I myself am hardly a strategy player, preferring simple and obvious games, yet I have so much fun with Galcon 2. Now that it's free there is no excuse not to give it a try!
